>>>> [IBM tool] to reduce the size of Java code. [...]
>>>> minimizes the length of names where possible ([...]).
>>>> Using this and other techniques they typically shrink
>>>> Java code by well over 50% for a small one-time cost
>>>> in terms of computer cycles (it takes about 4 minutes
>>>> to process 3.8 MB of code on an 800 MHz PC).

>>> That's an interesting assertion.  I'm not sure that I
>>> can relate it to the presence or absence of comments,
>>> particularly since comments don't end up in the compiled
>>> code.

>--- Jim Dixon <jdd@d...> wrote:
>> Of course.  But one of the subthreads in this discussion
>> is that comments can be made unnecessary by, for example,
>> appropriate choice of variable/method/class/etc names.
>> This is something that we all do, I imagine.
>> 
>> But the longer and more meaningful the names, the slower
>> the code ;-)

--- Ron Jeffries <ronjeffries@X...> wrote:
> In what language is this true, and why?


It's easy to see how, in Java and .Net, longer and more meaningful 
method, parameter and [in Java] local variable names can 
increase "compiled" class sizes, and hence load time.  These 
languages include a significant amount of metadata ("source code" 
information) in their "compiled" class files.  Therefore, longer 
names will cause some slight increase in the time needed to read the 
files, download the "executable" code across a slow network, and 
possibly even the time needed to process the "code" once loaded.  
(Though that last point is questionable, unless the machine is so low 
on memory that it must resort to paging to process "in memory" data.)

However, in most applications, run time is much longer than load 
time, and the Just In Time (JIT) Java compilers will render symbol 
name length irrelevant as they translate to machine code.

Of course, there's still some cost, in memory, to maintaining all 
this reflection / "linker" / "debugger" symbolic information in 
memory.  But I don't see any reason to be concerned about it unless 
overall measurements of actual application performance indicate that 
there's a problem.  And if there is a real performance issue, we can 
certainly use tools, such as the IBM tools mentioned above, to 
eliminate much of this extraneous and unnecessary debugging 
information from the production builds.
